subject: New York, New York
event:
New York Giants 37 Arizona Cardinals 29

New York Jets 34 Tennessee Titans 13

What can I possibly add?  Life is magical and full of joy.

The Jets win a huge one, upsetting the previously unbeaten Tennessee team that stole their original name (guess this was a true 'clash of the titans').  Not only did they win, but they dominated throughout.

And the Giants went down to Arizona and defeated a game and explosive Cardinals team that had not lost a home game all season.  That one had me on the edge of my seat all the way.  With that receiving corps, the Cards are never out of it till the last tick of the clock.

Two great wins.

I know, I know, the odds are against it... but for the first time since 1986, it now appears that there exists a slim chance that we could actually get a Subway Superbowl.  And wouldn't that be something?  Of course, since I love both teams, there is the danger that my head would explode.

Don't want to get ahead of myself, however.  There's a lot more football to play.

comments.upictitle: A Work In Progress: Sherlock reading
comments.article: Whoa, the Titans lost? That is a HUGE upset, no matter how good a player Favre is. My sports coworker will be very happy--he chose the Jets to win this week while his opponent chose the Titans. Awesome sauce.

I was really looking foward to the Jets-Broncos game but the Broncos utter, terrible collapse against the Raiders still has me screaming.

It's going to be a long week. Go Colts.

As a woman married to a devout Raider fan, all I can say is, "My home is joyful tonight". I don't do football pools, but my guess is the Autumn Wind has blown a stiff breeze for overall pool results.

It is what it is.

comments.upictitle: Names Is For Tombstones, Baby: Rocketeer
comments.article: So who would you root for, if that happened?

Life is magical and full of joy, indeed!

Spent five hours...six? I don't know...in the library researching medieval Nottinghamshire and thus missed the Jets game, but that's a good thing because they would not have won had I watched.

J-E-T-S JETS JETS JETS


Keep the dream alive!
But... Medieval nottinghamshire!

Well, though I will give the Jets credit for a job well done, and have to say the Titans were not at all themselves, I also have to say that was the worst officiating I've ever seen in the NFL.

I watched Courtland Finnegan grabbed roughly and spun to the ground hard by a member of the Jets offense after the play was over, without provocation, and ... no flag. There were a number of other very, very iffy calls.

I sat in LP Field kinda stunned over those - they made a major impact on the game, and I like a good game. I have no problem with the Jets playing better ball on a given day, and I think it's good for the Titans at this point to have something to keep them humble.

But what I saw today on the part of the officials, that was a total failure to do their job on multiple occasions - game changing occasions.

I've also never, in 8 years of having season tickets, seen Fisher that upset with the refs. He usually keeps his cool admirably, but this, again, was something different. And profoundly disappointing.

I agree there were some glaringly obvious calls that should have been made and weren't. The sad thing is some of the worst (for our Titans) calls were very much deserved. What was up with Carr? He kept getting called for interference over and over. At first I was shouting things I won't repeat here about the refs, but watching the replays he just played very stupid.

Either way it's like you said. The Titans have something to keep them humble and a very big reason to play better should the two meet again in the playoffs.

Mr. Martin, the day is yours, but don't count the Titans out just yet. Round 2 could well be on the way. ;-)
comments.subject: Sad Day

comments.article:
I'm boggling over calling it a "Subway Superbowl". I had no idea there was subway service to the New Jersey Meadowlands.

*daha*

Wouldn't it be the Meadowlands Series since both teams play their home games there?

Or better yet the first All Jersey series!
OH HELL YEAH
More like the "Walk Across The Field Super Bowl" (since my planned comment about the lack of subways in the Meadowlands was already done).
PATH train series?  Maybe both teams could do half time in NYC just so they can keep claiming they're from New York.

Oi. I think New Yorkers have big enough heads. I hate subway series of any kind. (As a Braves fan, I loathe both the Yankees and Mets.) I don't think it's good for the sport ( any sport) to have both teams in the championship game from the same city.

That said, who would you route for if that happened? I'm guessing the Giants.

I live in Arizona, but I'm from New York which left me a little torn about the game today. On the one hand, Fuck Arizona. Seriously. But on the other, it seems the Cards are finally drawing an audience this year- must have something to do with both not having to play in a college arena anymore, and also having a winning record. So on that score, it feels morally defensible to root for a traditionally underdog team.

what decided it for me was Kurt Warner's "prayer circle" he used to do (still does?) before games, as though putting trust in Jesus Christ will overcome a beastly offensive line that gives Eli enough time to throw those 30 yard strikes.

As a Diehard Green Bay fan I find myself also rooting for the Jets this year, because of my beloved Favre.  My husband's dream of the perfect Superbowl is much like your own - Green Bay vs. The Jets.  And his head would explode while trying to decide who to cheer for - his beloved Favre or the Pack.  I'm afraid in that case I'd have to go with the Pack - sorry GRRM!
comments.subject: Go Favre!

comments.article:
An all NY super bowl would be pretty sweet, but you'd have to call it the 'Turnpike' Bowl (or "Toilet" Bowl, depending on your feelings about Jersey) or something similar.

How I do wish the Jets had seriously looked at a stadium in Flushing Meadow next to Shea/Citifield. It would be nice to have one real NY football team that actually was in the city limits. I'm sick of Buffalo fans claiming to be the only true NY team. May as well be Canadian ;-)
comments.subject: Subway?

comments.article: The owners aren't rich enough for them to build their own stadium. If the Jets and Giants make it to the Superbowl it won't be a Subway Superbowl even though you can take mass-transit from NYC to the Meadowlands. They'll be playing in one stadium in Tampa. Maybe Snowbird Superbowl might be more appropriate.
comments.subject: Re: Subway?

comments.article: Congrats to both of your teams, George!
Wow! Who'da thunk it. The Jets dominating the Titans was eye-opening. G-men had another workman like performance. As far the Superbowl goes, them Cowboys are starting to ride. I'm nervous about them.

The Giants-Cards was on national TV, and it was a good game. They have a pretty tough schedule from here to the end, but if they survive the remainder of the season, there won't be any team they will have to worry about in the playoffs. The Jets might have a tougher time of it - they have an easier remaining schedule (much easier in fact), but they could run into some buzz saws in the playoffs. As the Giants proved last year, and Indy the year before, consistently winning tough games into and through the playoffs gets you into the Super Bowl.
comments.subject: NY, NY

comments.article:
George, you don't want it, trust me.

I've been a lifelong Steelers and Seahawks fan since I started watching football in the late 70s. When they faced off in Super Bowl XL, the whole experience was a major letdown.

I was still angry about Neil O'Donnell costing the Steelers the championship against Dallas a few years back with those two awful interceptions, and finally when the Steelers make it back to the SB, it's against Seattle! On the other side, the Seahawks were one of the worst teams in the league for well over a decade, and the one year they make it to the Super Bowl, it's against the Steelers... ridiculous!

THEN the game had some of the worst officiating in the history of football, the officials pretty much handed the Steelers the game. I had truly nobody to root for until the officials were so blatantly one-sided that I ended up rooting for the Hawks just out of disgust!

and living in Pittsburgh made this even worse for me, cause all the locals would just annoy me saying how the Steelers deserved that game, even though pretty much everyone else across the country openly admitted it was a farce.

But even with one of my teams winning no matter what, I can't say I enjoyed the experience one bit. It took all the fun out of it.
comments.subject: Subway Superbowl

comments.article: Indeed, it was the worst officiated game in NFL history.  In my mind, the game was fixed.  Seattle dominated for most of the first half, but every time the 'Hawks got a big play, there was a phantom holding call. Plus, the Roethlesberger TD that wasn't a TD upheld on review.  Then the non-replay of Darrell Jackson's catch for a TD ruled out of bounds as time expired in the first half. That game still stinks, and there was a call for a Congressional investigation into the officiating which was subsequently squashed.
comments.subject: SB XL

comments.article:
For some reason in the world of sports coverage and commentary an undefeated team is untouchable. The Titans have a good football team, but the Giants have been a stronger team than them from day 1 no matter what ESPN's Power Rankings have shown. You do not go 10-0 without being good, but very few of the Titans' wins have been against quality opponents. They had a good win, not to mention a tight one, at Baltimore early on and beat the Colts before Indy hit their stride. With that credit now given through gritted teeth, I'm not at all surprised the Jets, who are on fire right now, put it in on them today. Favre looks good in green, baby.

senorb: There is "always" someone to worry about in the playoffs. Remember the Giants last year? Dallas beat them twice in the regular season and came in at 13-3 but those two factoids didn't keep me from worrying about the G-Men or get the Boys past round 2. If the Cowboys keep winning and make it into the playoffs this year, they might be revisiting the Meadowlands in January and I can assure you that if that happens Brad Johnson won't be their QB. It'll be some kid from Wisconsin who's got a really good road record (especially against the G-Men). Even if the Boys don't make it in or win a single game thereafter, there are always surprises in the playoffs...always.

All rants aside, I like the Giants. :D I mean, really, they're just likeable. Awww, shucks, did I just admit that? Maybe it's just that I hate the Eagles and Skins so much that I gotta go easy on one of the other Beasts.
comments.subject: Vote No to Favre/Manning and Yes to Favre/Romo

comments.article:
Life is magical and full of joy.

Try telling that to the Chiefs or their fans. 1-19 for the season. Too painful to watch.

You're all kidding yourselves.  Everyone who's anyone knows the Vikings are where it's at.  Adrian Peterson himself was quoted the other day, saying that "If ADWD is finished by the time the Super Bowl gets here, I promise not to embarass the Jretts too much."  That's just what I heard. Of course, the g-funky bunch would face his wrath in the playoffs, but one can only hold back the tide so long. :)
comments.subject: Tom Foolery

comments.article: Can we get Favre back?  I was not exactly happy with the Packers' management when they balked at the opportunity to get Favre back.  The old man has pretty much spent the season proving that my gut was right on the matter and that the packers leadership had their heads up their asses.

I'm in a suicide pool that started with several thousand participants. We're now down to two hundred, and I'm still alive. I've saved the Giants all year, and am thinking of using them against Washington this week. Can you guarantee that the G-Men will win or tie this next weekend? Please? I'd really appreciate it.

comments.upictitle: Darth Paradox: Colette - Zounds (Return To Sender)
comments.article: Fascinating.  You have to pick a different team to win each week?

When the Colts played the Bears I felt both joy and stress. Fortunately, I was leaning toward the Colts because I had already seen the Bears win one back in '86 (Super Bowl XX). Not only that, it was good to see Tony Dungy and Peyton Manning finally win the big game. If it does end up Jets-Giants, I'll have to go with the Jets despite loving the Giants for beating the Pats last year in the greatest SB ever. The reason: Thomas Jones. The Bears should have NEVER let him go!!
comments.subject: I feel your potential pain

comments.article:
BAH! The Giants have to get past my Falcons first! *waits for laughter to stop* Yes yes, I realize the Falcons do not have a legitimate shot at making it to the show. However, I have to show my support every now and then. For those of us who have suffered through the Falcons' horrible history, its nice to have a ray of hope. Regardless of how slim it is. I do look forward to the next 5 to tens years in Atlanta.

Grats to the Jets and Giants. My hat is off to them and their success this year! So far anyway.
comments.subject: Subway Superbowl!

comments.article: I'm sorry, but there will be no Subway Superbowl this year as the Bucs are going to go all the way and have the mother of all home field advantages.  :)  W00t!!

We in Chicago this year briefly had hopes for a Crosstown Classic World Series, but reality soon came crashing in.  Best of luck to both New York teams in this endeavor.  As a Detroit kid living in Chicago, I have no football team to root for anymore.
